coredata.dc:title: Dendrite-free lithium anode via polyether block polyamide in solid polymer electrolyte for all solid state lithium metal batteries

coredata.dc:description: Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) applied to all-solid-state lithium metal batteries (ASSLMBs) can construct energy storage devices with high safety and high energy density. However, it restricts the application due to the low ionic conductivity and slow lithium transport of SPEs lead the inhomogeneous deposition of Li. Herein, a free-standing SPEs designed by introducing polyether block amide (Pebax) and polyethylene glycol (PEG) as additive to obtain the inspired PP-SPE, which can be prepared at scale. PEG addition helped Pebax connecting to form a network structure. Through the synergistic effect of Li+ and ether oxygen or carbonyl group in Pebax. which promoted the rapid lithium transport and exhibited a high ionic conductivity of 4.27 × 10−4 S cm−1 (room temperature) and a relative high lithium ion transference number (0.44). In addition, the prepared SPEs had good mechanical properties (5.1 MPa). The highly stable interface with lithium metal was maintained for more than 600 h at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2, and no dendrite growth observed. The capacity of the Li//LFP cell was 108 mAh g−1 at room temperature and 0.5C with 96.5 % capacity retention after 300 cycles. Thus, PP-SPE provides a new strategy for the safety and high energy density of commercialization ASSLMBs.

Free standing solid polymer electrolyte
All solid state lithium metal battery
Dendrite-free

head.ce:title: Dendrite-free lithium anode via polyether block polyamide in solid polymer electrolyte for all solid state lithium metal batteries

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: College of Materials Science & Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, 100124 Beijing, China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) applied to all-solid-state lithium metal batteries (ASSLMBs) can construct energy storage devices with high safety and high energy density. However, it restricts the application due to the low ionic conductivity and slow lithium transport of SPEs lead the inhomogeneous deposition of Li. Herein, a free-standing SPEs designed by introducing polyether block amide (Pebax) and polyethylene glycol (PEG) as additive to obtain the inspired PP-SPE, which can be prepared at scale. PEG addition helped Pebax connecting to form a network structure. Through the synergistic effect of Li+ and ether oxygen or carbonyl group in Pebax. which promoted the rapid lithium transport and exhibited a high ionic conductivity of 4.27 × 10−4 S cm−1 (room temperature) and a relative high lithium ion transference number (0.44). In addition, the prepared SPEs had good mechanical properties (5.1 MPa). The highly stable interface with lithium metal was maintained for more than 600 h at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2, and no dendrite growth observed. The capacity of the Li//LFP cell was 108 mAh g−1 at room temperature and 0.5C with 96.5 % capacity retention after 300 cycles. Thus, PP-SPE provides a new strategy for the safety and high energy density of commercialization ASSLMBs.

Pebax and PEG form a Li+ transport network that utilizes the presence of functional groups C=O and C-O-C to make the Li anode dendrite-free.
Unlabelled Image

ce:keyword.ce:text: All solid state lithium metal battery

ce:data-availability.ce:para: The authors do not have permission to share data.

ce:section.ce:para: Lithium metal batteries (LMBs) become a research hotspot in the field of energy storage due to Li anode inside with remarkable advantages, such as excellent theoretical specific capacity (up to 3860 mAh g−1), superior cycling stability, no memory effect, and low electrochemical potential (−3.04 V with respect to standard hydrogen electrodes) [1,2]. These advantages endow LMB great potential in high energy density applications [3,4]. However, problems of the present organic liquid electrolytes used in LMBs cannot be ignored, including flammability, leakage, and the tendency to produce dendrites during charging and discharging, which might penetrate the diaphragm and cause serious safety issues such as abnormal exothermic phenomenon, spontaneous combustion, and even explosion, which greatly limits the practical application of LMBs [5–7]. Therefore, solid-state electrolyte (SSE) becomes an effective strategy to solve the safety problems [8–10]. SSE-equipped all-solid-state lithium metal batteries (ASSLMBs) have demonstrated excellent performance in realizing high energy density and been considered one of the important trends of LMBs batteries in the future [11–13].

Among SSEs, solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) consisting of polymer matrix and the lithium salts, have attracted much attention due to their facile preparation, adjustable shape and size and good affinity with electrodes [14–16]. Polyethylene oxide (PEO) has been one of the focus of SPEs research due to its good solubility and high flexibility towards lithium salts [17]. But the high crystallinity and low dielectric constant of PEO lead to its low ionic conductivity (less than 10−5 S cm−1) at ambient and severe ionic aggregation, which draw back the transport of lithium ions and limits the SPE application of PEO [18,19]. Numerous strategies have been employed to improve mechanical strength and ionic conductivity of electrolytes. For example, blending PEO with polymers, such as polyphenylene oxide (PPO) [20], polystyrene (PS) [21], and Poly(propylene monothiocarbonate) (PPMTC) [22] to improve their comprehensive performance. Recently, multiple Block Copolymer Electrolytes (BCEs) with high ionic conductivity and high toughness are reported to have a ions conductive components consisting of poly(propylene oxide) and polyether segments [23,24].

Seeking of the new system was inspired by the structure and role of PEO in SPEs, commercial polyether block amide (Pebax) consists of a flexible polyether chain (PE in PTMEG) and a rigid polyamide chain (PA12). PE chain is structurally similar to PEO with excellent thermal and chemical stability, but has less oxygen heteroatoms in the main chain, resulting in a lower spatial concentration of oxygen solvation sites in the PE chain for Li-O, which contributes to higher lithium ion conductivity and transference number [25]. The unique -CONH amide bonding and abundant hydrogen bonding network structure in the PA12 chain confer excellent elasticity and mechanical strength [26,27]. The large number of negatively charged amide groups also gives PA the potential to transport ion [28] as spacers between the structural domains of the polyether, which hinder its crystallization and improve the mobility of Li+ through the ether bond [29,30]. However, Pebax is not mechanically strong enough, and form effective ion transport channels for Li+ which makes the inhomogeneous deposition of Li. Chen et al. [33] used a polyether block amide polymer, Pebax, as a matrix and poly(ethylene glycol dimethyl ether) (PEGDE) as a conditioner to obtain a freestanding SPE electrolytes, presenting ionic conductivity of 4.47 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 60 °C and present an ultralong lifespan. However, the performance of SPE at room temperature did not report.

In this work, Pebax was employed as a polymer matrix to prepare a free-standing SPEs by introducing polyethylene glycol (PEG) and then crosslinking. The weak coordination of functional groups C-O-C and C=O present in Pebax materials with Li facilitated the rapid transport of lithium ions [31–33], whereas the addition of PEG with the PE chains of Pebax formed interconnected Li+ transport channels [34,35], which enhanced the affinity between SPE and lithium anode, and improving the uniform deposition of Li. the rigid-flexible interactions between Pebax and PEG resulted in a significant enhancement of the PP-SPE in terms of mechanical strength and flexibility compared to those of Pebax SPE. Li//LFP batteries containing PP-SPE exhibit excellent cycling stability, which provides a prospective trend for the development of high performance ASSLMBs.

Pebax was purchased from Arkema S. A. (France) Polyethylene Glycol (PEG, Mw = 1500), and N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP, AR) were bought from Aladdin Tech. Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Lithium bis (trifluoromethane)sulfonimide (LiTFSI, 99 %) was provided by Macklin Bio Tech. Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). LiTFSI was vacuum dried before use.

Pebax and PEG were added to NMP with vigorous stirring at 60 °C until fully dissolved and form a homogeneous solution, and then LiTFSI (mass fraction 35 %) which was dried in vacuum added with stirring evenly. The casting polymer solution was scraped and coated on the PTFE mold, dried at 25 °C for 24 h, and then placed in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 48 h to further remove the residual solvent. Pebax without LiFTSI named Pebax membrane. The electrolytes with PEG content of 0 %, 5 %, 10 %, 15 % and 20 % were marked Pebax-SPE, PP-SPE5%, PP-SPE10%, PP-SPE15%, PP-SPE20%, in which the sample of PP-SPE10% as a delegation was referred to as PP-SPE.

Surface morphologies of the SPE (after gold sputtering) and cycled Li anode were observed by SU8020 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) (Hitachi, Japan). The elemental composition of the SPE was analyzed by attached energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). The structure of the electrolyte materials was characterized using a TENSOR 27 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (Bruker, Germany). Phase analysis was performed using a D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) at a 2 θ (degree) range of 5° to 40°. The thermal stability of the electrolyte membrane was tested under the conditions of N2 atmosphere, in the range 25–800 °C and 20 °C min−1 heating rate using a STA 449 F3 synchronous thermal analyzer (NETZSCH, Germany). The melting point and phase transition temperature of SPE were measured by DSC 214 differential scanning calorimeter (NETZSCH, Germany) in the temperature range of −80 °C to 50 °C and the heating rate of 10 °C min−1.The mechanical properties of the SPE were characterized by the stress-strain curve at room temperature measured by a Labthink-C610M intelligent electronic tensile testing machine (Languang, China) under the conditions of a loading rate of 10 mm min−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, K-Alpha X-ray Photoelectron Spectrometer was performed on the K-ALPHA, Thermo Fisher, USA) was performed using an Al Kα X-ray source to characterize the composition of the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) of the Li electrode.

A mixture containing LiFePO4, Super P, and PVDF (8:1:1 mass ratio) was ground for 30 min, Subsequently, the NMP was dipped into the mixed materials and stirred at room temperature to form a homogeneous looking slurry. Finally, the resulting slurry was painted onto aluminum foil and dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h to form the electrode. The prepared LFP electrodes were cutting into 14mm diameter disk electrodes (the surface density of the LFP electrode is 1.8 ± 0.3 mg cm−2). The type-2023 coin cells were assembled using the prepared LFP disk electrode for the subsequent testing (Li plates for the anode, LFP for the cathode and with the investigated SPEs).

The Li//Li, Li//SS, SS//SS and Li//LFP cells were fabricated using 2032-type coin cells for all electrochemical tests. In the Li//LFP cells, metallic Li served as the anode, and LFP electrode was used as the cathode. These components were successively assembled and the cells were subjected to electrochemical performance testing. Charge and discharge tests of the coin batteries were conducted using a Neware battery test system (Neware, China). The system was used to assess the stability of the Li anode and evaluate the cycling and rate performances of the cells in the voltage range of 2.5–4.0 V. Electrochemical measurements were including the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), Li+ transference number (tLi +), ionic conductivity (σ), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). LSV was tested using a Li//SS battery with a scan rate of 0.5 mV s−1 in the voltage range of 2.0–5.5 V. The stability of Li//Li symmetric cell containing SPE was tested at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 (capacity of 0.1 mAh cm−2).

Stainless steel SS was used as the blocker of ion conductivity, SS//SS coin cells containing SPEs assembled. The ionic conductivity of SPE was measured by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) with a frequency range of 106 to 0.1 Hz at open circuit potential OCP and an amplitude of 10 mV. The measurement was carried out from 25 °C to 85 °C. The conductivity was calculated by eq. (1):
(1)

Here, L is the thickness of the SPE (cm), S is the surface area of the electrode (cm2), and

The activation energy (E a) [36,37] can be determined by measuring the ionic conductivity changes at different temperatures (25–85 °C) and then fitting the data according to the Arrhenius eq. (2):

) was measured by combining AC impedance method and chronoamperometry. The Li//Li battery was subjected to a polarization potential of 10 mV and the interfacial impedance and current of the battery was measured before and after polarization. The lithium ion transference number is calculated by the eq. (3):

ce:section.ce:section-title: The morphology, structure and stability of the PP-SPE
ce:section.ce:para: Pebax consists of a PA chain (PA12) providing mechanical rigid properties and a PE chain (PTMEG) providing flexibility and interfacial compatibility (Fig. S1). As showed in Fig. 1a, the design of SPE exhibited. Pebax has a PE chain that could be interlinked with the ether group of PEG as a network structure to build a continuous Li+ conductive channel. Fulfilled the designation, a free standing PP-SPE prepared. As shown in Fig. 1b, the optical image of the free standing PP-SPE looked with a smooth surface and transparent appearance. It showed with a good elasticity and toughness. And PP-SPE can be prepared in a large area, it could reach up to 22 × 13 cm in dimension (Fig. S2) in present work.

Surface morphology of PP-SPE was observed by Scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The surface looked compact, smooth, bright and dark. In addition, the EDS spectra show that LiTFSI was uniformly distributed in the electrolyte (Fig. 1c), indicating that the PP-SPE structure favored the dissociation LiTFSI without aggregation.

The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra analyzed the chemical structure of the electrolyte and the coordination environment of Li+. From Fig. 1e that the Pebax showed characteristic peaks at 1108 cm−1 (C-O-C stretching in PE), 1640 cm−1 (C=O stretching in PA), and 3300 cm−1 (NH stretching in PA). As shown in Fig. 1e, the peak of C-O-C at 1108 cm−1 in the PE chain blue shifts due to the coordination with Li+ after the addition of LiTFSI [38]. On the contrary, the characteristic peaks of NH and C=O in the PA chain also have a similar red shift, which may be due to the hydrogen bonding between NH2 and TFSI− [39] and the coordination between Li+ and C=O [40], which could enhance the transport of Li+. After the addition of PEG, the peak of C-O-C move to high wavenumber, but the peak of C=O move to low wavenumber, the PEG and PE chains would form a network structure to construct an interoperable Li+ transport channel [34], and there would be more groups are coordinated with Li+.

Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was used to characterize the phase transition behavior and chain motion of the electrolyte in the range of −80–50 °C (Fig. S3 and Table S1). The glass transition temperature T g of Pebax SPE is −66.49 °C. With the increase of PEG content, the T g of the polymer electrolyte decreases, because the introduction of PEG decreased the crystallinity and might increase the flexibility of the segment and promote the segment movement of the electrolyte. The transport process of Li+ is usually described as the movement of polymer chains and the association/separation of Li+ and polar groups in the amorphous phase domain. Thus, a high proportion of amorphous domains and a low T g are favorable for Li+ transport [41,42].

X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed to examine the crystallinity of PP-SPE. As shown in Fig. S4, there were two peaks in the diffraction pattern of Pebax membrane, but in the result of Pebax-SPE, the peaks merge to one, and the intensity of peaks reduced and became wide. It indicated that the crystallinity was significantly reduced after Li salt addition. Which might be attributed to the coordination between the polymer and Li+ interfering with the chain segment stacking behavior, which could facilitate the rapid transport of Li [14,43]. When PEG was added in the Pebax base SPE, the weaken and widen of the only peak indicated that crystallinity of PP-SPE was reduced also. Low crystallization of PP-SPE would promote the transport of Li+.

The thermal stability of PP-SPEs with different PEG content was determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in the range of 20–800 °C. As shown in Fig. S5, there are no obvious different among 5 samples. The electrolytes can maintain good thermal stability at 220 °C, all the samples and designed SPEs meet the requirements of high-temperature resistance in practical applications of solid electrolytes.

The mechanical properties of PP-SPEs were measured by tensile tests. As shown in Fig. S6, the PP-SEP5% tensile strength was about 4 MPa. It was about twice of Pebax-SPE (2.2 MPa). When PEG content increased to 10 % in SPE, the tensile strength of PP-SPE 10 % increased also. The tensile strength was with an excellent 5.1 MPa and the elongation was at break of 1307.3 %. This contributed to the presence of amide structure in the polymer matrix which gives the electrolyte strong mechanical properties [44]. This is due to the fact that Pebax combines the rigidity of polyamide with the flexibility of polyether. This structure gives Pebax excellent mechanical strength and high resilience, while PEG is a flexible polymer whose polyether chain segment is easy to interact with cations, making it solvated and easy to form a uniform system. Appropriate amount of polyethylene glycol can increase the flexibility and ductility of the polymer material. But the tensile strength of PP-SPE15% and PP-SPE20% decreased when the PEG content continued to increase. As shown in Fig. S7, the SEM images show the microstructure changes of PP-SPE with different PEG content, and the structural integrity of the material changes as the PEG content increases, especially above 10 %. A transition from a relatively uniform and continuous structure at lower PEG content to a more fragmented and discontinuous structure at higher PEG content. This structural discontinuity is more pronounced in samples containing 15 % and 20 % PEG (d and e). This may be attributed to the small molecular weight of PEG which leads to discontinuities in the SPE structure, resulting in a significant decrease in the mechanical properties. PP-SPE 10 %has the optimal mechanical properties with a significant advantage over PEO SPEs (< 1 MPa) [45,46].The high mechanical properties of the SPE could play a good barrier role for Li dendritic growth in the battery, during charge and discharge cycle. This would promote the stability and safety of the all-solid-state lithium metal battery (ASSLMBs).

ce:section.ce:section-title: The electrochemical performances of the PP-SPE
ce:section.ce:para: As shown in Fig. 2a, the conductivity test using SS//SS showed that the lithium ion conductivity of Pebax SPE was 1.48 × 10−4 S cm−1 at 25 °C, which was larger than the current reported PEO SPE ionic conductivity [47]. The C-O-C and C=O groups in Pebax both have complexing activities for Li+, and the Li+ transport process is carried out in Pebax-SPEs through complexation-dissociation-complexation. With the increasing of the addition amount of PEG, the ionic conductivity of SPE increased, but when the addition amount of PEG over 10 %, the ionic conductivity of SPE decreased with the increase of the adding amount of PEG. Ionic conductivity of PP-SPE10% reached 4.27 × 10−4 S cm−1 (Fig. 2a), the highest ionic conductivity among samples. The ionic conductivity test results are consistent with the mechanical properties test results (Fig.S6). When the amount of PEG is 10 %, the micro structure of the Pebax matrix is changed (Fig. 1c), and appropriate amount of PEG can increase the flexibility and ion channel of the material, thereby improving the ionic conductivity and mechanical properties. The degree of cross-linking within the polymer influenced the ionic conductivity also. From the present result, the network structure formed by Pebax and PEG is the most suitable when the PEG content is 10 %. The Pebax and PEG molecules interacted with proper ratio. When the PEG content is too high, the interaction of Pebax and PEG may be oversaturated, the overmount of PEG molecules may interact each other [48], and saturate the functional groups which could coordinate the Li+. It is leading to a decrease in the ionic conductivity that limiting the movement of the Li+ in polymer chains.

Resistance of electrolyte is key for batteries, as reciprocal, the conductivity of polymer electrolytes has a great dependence on temperature. Fig. 2b showed the dependence of the ionic conductivity of PP-SPEs on temperature, the higher the temperature, the faster ion migration rate and the typical Vogel-Tammann-Fulcher (VTF) behavior observed [49,50]. As shown in Fig. S8, the ionic conductivity of PP-SPEs increased with temperature in the range of 25 to 85 °C. When the temperature was 85 °C, the ionic conductivity reached the level closed to that of liquid electrolyte (~ 10−3 S cm−1). The ion migration activation energy (E
a ) of the PP-SPE can be calculated by the VTF empirical formula. As shown in Table. S2, the E
a of the PP-SPE10% is 0.1032 eV, which is much lower than other PP-SPEs and PEO SPE [51], indicating that Li+ has a low potential barrier during the movement inside the electrolyte and is easier to achieve rapid transport of Li+. And the ASSLMBs with PP-SPE10% would have a good room temperature property.

Li+ transference number of PP-SPE was tested by Li//Li symmetric cells. As shown in Fig. 2c and Fig. S9, the Li+ transference number of PP-SPE was 0.44, which was higher than that of Pebax-SPE (0.35).The high Li+ transference number and ionic conductivity of PP-SPE reflect the efficient transport of Li+, which is favorable for the uniform distribution of space charge near the anode, thus preventing the deposition of Li dendrites at the interface [52,53].

As shown in Fig. 2d, the electrochemical stability of PP-SPE was investigated by linear scanning voltammetry (LSV). The electrochemical stability window (ESW) of PP-SPE was higher at 5.1 V than that of Pebax-SPE (4.9 V). They were might be attributed to the interaction of amine and ether groups in the SPE to form hydrogen bonds. The formation of hydrogen bonds reduces the electron cloud density around the C-O-C, which produces a strong shielding effect and thus improves its electrochemical stability [54,55].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Interfacial compatibility and stability between PP-SPE and Li anode
ce:section.ce:para: Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was applied to investigate the bulk resistance (Rb) and interfacial impedance (Ri) of Li//Li symmetrical cells at different waiting time. Interfacial compatibility between the PP-SPE with Li electrodes was evaluated for the potential of PP-SPE in practical applications.

As shown in Fig. 3a and 3b, R b kept stable over the first 12 h, while R i increased slightly. This indicates that the network structure composed of Pebax and PEG gives PP-SPE good stability, and interfacial compatibility through the interaction of C-O-C and C=O with Li+. There were some reaction at the interface between SPE and Li electrode. As shown in Figs. 3c and 3d, with the increase of the last waiting time, R b remained stable in 14 days, while Ri increased from 707 Ω to 802 Ω in the first 4 days, then continued decreased to 588 Ω, and after 11 day it remained relatively stable. It could be inferred that the R b of PP-SPE is stable at test time, and the R i of PP-SPE increase at initial time and keep stable after decade. The long waiting time sable of R i is due to the good interfacial stability between the PP-SPE and the Li anode, which results in the formation of an Solid Electrolyte Interface (SEI) between the PP-SPE and the Li anode, effectively suppressing the increase in interfacial resistance [56]. This would help to promote the uniform deposition of Li+, thus improving the safety and stability of the battery.

Plating/stripping tests of Li//Li symmetric cells were performed at a current density of 0.1 mAcm−2 and a capacity of 0.1 mAh cm−2 to study the nucleation and growth behavior of lithium. Fig. 3e shows that the Li//Li symmetric cell equipped with PP-SPE cycle stably without short-circuiting for 600 h, displaying highly reversible lithium stripping and plating behaviors, which is attributed to the strong mechanical properties and network structure of PP-SPE to keep the symmetric cell stable. The inset shows that the polarization voltage is stable at about 45 mV and remains stable over time, which is attributed to the presence of C-O-C and C=O in the PP-SPE, which promotes the rapid transport of Li and contributes to the maintenance of a stable polarization voltage.

To further investigate the stability of the electrolyte and interface and its inhibition of Li dendrite growth, the Li//Li symmetric cell was disassembled after 600 h of cycling and the lithium anode was observed by SEM. Compared with the fresh Li anode (Fig. 3f), the surface of lithium anode after 600 h cycling remained smooth and dense, and no lithium dendrite growth was observed (Fig. 3g). These results indicate that PP-SPE has a significant inhibition effect on the free growth of lithium dendrites. This favorable dendrite inhibition effect is attributed to the network channels and functional groups of PP-SPE, which promote the uniform deposition of Li+ and thus improve the cycling stability of the battery.

In addition, XPS was applied to analyze the chemical composition of the SEI layer on the surface of the lithium electrode after cycling. Lithium sheet from the Li//Li battery after 50 cycles was used, and the results of C and F are shown in Fig. S10. The C 1s spectra of the lithium electrode surfaces of PP-SPE (Fig. S10a) showed the presence of CO, C=O, and other organic chemical bonds, suggesting the involvement of the SPE in the formation of the SEI layer. As shown in Fig. S10b, a certain amount of LiF was present in the SEI layer formed by PP-SPE. CF2 can form a uniform SEI with LiF, and the formed SEI layer exhibits excellent flexibility and chemical stability [57], while providing an ion channel for Li+ to pass through the SEI layer. It facilitates Li+ transfer and also improves the inter facial affinity between the electrolyte and lithium metal, so that the PP-SPE has the smallest over potential with the best cycling stability.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Performance test of PP-SPEs in Li//LFP cells
ce:section.ce:para: The Li//LFP coin cells were assembled to evaluate the practical application of PP-SPE in ASSLMBs. As shown in Fig. 4a, the Li//LFP cells were charged-discharged at rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, and 0.5C, and the cells had a discharge specific capacity of 142 mAh g−1, 131 mAh g−1, 110 mAh g−1, and 98 mAh g−1 respectively. When the rate returns to 0.1C, the discharge capacity can be restored to 133 mA h g−1, showing good rate performance and capacity retention rate performance. Stable platforms (Fig. 4b) can be clearly observed on the charge-discharge curves at different rates. As shown in Fig. 4c, the charge-discharge curve of Li//LFP battery using PP-SPE at 45 °C and 0.1C, the fluctuation of voltage during test was arouse by the waving of the oven. The initial discharge specific capacity of Li//LFP was 141.7 mA h g−1, and the capacity retention rate was 73 % after 100 cycles without short circuit. Fig. 4d shows the long-term cycle stability of PP-SPE, with Li//LFP cells using PP-SPE showing higher initial specific capacity and better capacity retention at 0.5C. After 300 cycles, it still has a specific capacity of 101.6 mAh g−1, a capacity retention rate of 96.5 %, and a coulomb efficiency of about 99 %. The Li//LFP containing PP-SPE showed a flat charge-discharge curve with little voltage polarization after 300 cycles (Fig. S11). In contrast, the Li//LFP battery using the Pebax SPE has a faster capacity decay at 0.5C cycles, and the capacity retention rate is only 58.6 % after 100 cycles. This suggests that the network structure of PP-SPE and the presence of C-O-C and C=O groups promote the rapid migration of lithium, resulting in good battery cycling stability which is quite to previously reported Pebax/PEG ASSLMBs (Table S3).

Free-standing PP-SPE was successfully prepared by using Pebax as matrix and PEG as a continuous ion transport channel. PP-SPE can be scale preparation. It has plenty of functional C-O-C and C=O groups, resulting in high lithium-ion conductivity (4.27 × 10−4 S cm−1), relative high transference number of Li+ (0.44) and wide electrochemical stable window (5.1 V) at room temperature, as well as excellent mechanical properties (5.1 MPa, elongation at a break of 1307.3 %) and thermal stability (about 220 °C). The unique network structure ensures PP-SPE and Li electrode affinity (the polarization voltage of a symmetrical battery is about 45 mV) and homogenously Li deposition (the symmetrical battery runs for more than 600 h at 0.1mAh cm−2 capacity). These properties significantly improve the reversibility of lithium metal batteries by inhibiting dendritic growth and electrode-electrolyte side reactions. The assembled Li//LFP cells showed excellent rate performance and long-term cycle stability at relative high rates at room temperature (96.5 % capacity retention rate for 300 cycles at 0.5C). This novel SPE based on Pebax is competitive in developing the next generation of ASSLMBs.

Zihao Wang: Writing – review & editing, Writing – original draft, Investigation, Conceptualization. Mingye Li: Writing – review & editing, Investigation. Qing Ding: Writing – review & editing, Investigation. Peipei Ding: Writing – review & editing. Fan Li: Writing – review & editing, Supervision, Funding acquisition. Hongxia Guo: Writing – review & editing, Supervision.
